list_page_teaser: Obi-Wan Kenobi and Yoda have similar personalities - and their spiritual portraits are similar as well.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
This gallery contains spiritual portraits of the main Jedi Masters and droids in the first two Star Wars trilogies.

To see the personalities of main characters in the original trilogy, see the original trilogy gallery on this site. To see the personalities of main characters in the prequel trilogy — including Darth Vader and Emporer Palpatine — see the prequel trilogy gallery on this site.
story_html:
The spiritual portraits of Yoda and Obi-Wan Kenobi look very similar. The Blue shows that both Jedis prefer ideas to facts, and the Green shows they are much more rational than emotional.

In contrast, the spiritual portraits of the two droids look very different. The Yellow in both images shows that both are pragmatic, but that is where the similarities end.

The Red in C-3PO's image shows he is extremely emotional, and the long Yellow vertical line shows he's more out-going. Meanwhile, the Green in R2-D2's portrait shows he is extremely rational, and the long horizontal Green line indicates he's more of a listener.

To learn more about a character's personality, click on their thumbnail to see a larger version, then click on the Show the Whole Story button to read the character's story.

image_list.title: Yoda
image_list.subtitle_html: Grand Master of the Jedi Order
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Yoda's spiritual portrait shows he is, like Obi-Wan Kenobi, idealistic and logical.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Yoda's dominant personality trait, his strong preference for seeing the world more in terms of ideas than facts.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Yoda demonstrates this trait when he performs psychokinesis, using his powers of concentration to get The Force to move objects.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Yoda's auxiliary personality trait, his strong preference for making logical rather than emotional decisions.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Yoda demonstrates this trait when he remains focused when fighting, refusing to let emotions like fear interfere with his determination to vanquish his opponent.

image_list.title: C-3PO
image_list.subtitle_html: Humanoid Protocol Droid and Fluent Communicator
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: C-3PO's spiritual portrait shows he is pragmatic and emotional.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents C-3PO's dominant personality trait, his preference for facts over ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  C-3PO demonstrates this trait in his lack of concern for principles, theories and the big picture, and his focus on details, day-to-day events and the concerns of the current moment.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents C-3PO's auxiliary personality trait, his very strong preference for the emotional over the logical.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  C-3PO demonstrates this trait when he quickly becomes emotional during stressful times, interfering with problem-solving activities by complaining and looking for someone to blame.
image_list.story_intro_html:
Do the droids in Star Wars have personalities, and is it possible to draw them?

As far as the Groja program© goes, the answer to that question depends on the answers to these questions:

  1. Can the droid perceive facts, understand ideas, or both?
  2. Can the droid make decisions, using logic, emotions, or both?

Because the answer to both of these questions is Yes, then the answer to the original question is also positive. And so, having gone through the process of analyzing, drawing, and presenting C-3PO's portrait, the result appears above.

Three Fifths of a Person?

The droids on Star Wars may not be able to taste or smell, but they can certainly see and hear. And based on one poor power droid's screams while being tortured in the droid pool run by the sadistic EV-9D9, the sense of touch in at least some of them works as well.

Whether this makes these droids three fifths of a person is a question best left to philosophers. What matters here is, the droids have senses that can perceive — they can gather data as facts.

The Yellow in C-3PO's spiritual portrait represents this proclivity for sensing data. It's conceivable he might have programming enabling him to recognize some types of patterns — hence his image has a bit of Blue — but most of what C-3PO takes in is factual, not ideological.

Riding an Emotional Rollercoaster

C-3PO wears his heart on his sleeve and is constantly sharing his emotions. In just the first hour of Episode IV: A New Hope, C-3PO goes from bliss to misery.

Early in the film Luke Skywalker purchases C-3PO from the Jawas, and the droid is ecstatic about getting an oil bath:

Thank the maker! This oil bath is going to feel soooo good!
 — C-3PO in A New Hope, 1977 (19:30). [Emphasis added.]

Before too long C-3PO is terrified as he and his friends escape from Tattooine while under fire from Imperial Stormtroopers:

Oh my! I've forgotten how much I hate space travel!
 — C-3PO in A New Hope, 1977 (55:35). [Emphasis added.]

This emotional rollercoaster ride is a result of the programming C-3PO has received as a protocol droid. The nature of his programming becomes clear in a scene in which his head is attached to a battle droid's body and he's expected to fight:

What's all this noise? A-a battle? Oh, there's been some terrible mistake! I'm programmed for etiquette, not destruction!
 — C-3PO in Episode II: Attack of the Clones, 2002. [Emphasis added.]

The Red in C-3PO's spiritual portrait represents his proclivity for feeling and expressing his emotions.

3CPO's personality — and his spiritual portrait — stand in stark contrast to the portrait of his cool, calm, and collected comrade R2-D2. Because most droids are presumably programmed to be logical, the spiritual portraits of most of them would certainly contain more Green, and hence look more like that image of the cool-headed R2-D2, and less like this warm image of C-3PO.

Communication Difficulties

The book Star Wars Psychology: The Dark Side of the Mind contains a chapter about the psychology of the droids on Star Wars. It observes that some people, such as Luke and Anakin Skywalker, treat the droids with respect, while others, such as Han Solo and Obi-Wan Kenobi, are rude to them.

While everyone can understand C-3PO, the book notes how some people, including Luke and Anakin, can understand R2-D2's machine language — his bleeps, blurps, whistles, and raspberries. Their ability to communicate with R2-D2 may correlate with their willingness to show kindness to not just him but other droids as well.

While communication difficulties can certainly fuel prejudices, the negative attitude of people like Han and Obi-Wan towards droids could also have a basis in fear. There are several phobias related to droids, notably technophobia – the fear of technology, robophobia – the fear of robots, and cyberphobia or logizomechanophobia – the fear of computers.

Conclusion

[It is interesting that, although he has been programmed and is presumably logical, C-3PO shows precious little rationality.]

About This Portrait

This spiritual portrait is based on the first six Star Wars movies, both the original trilogy (1977-1980) and the prequel trilogy (1999-2005).

The book Star Wars Psychology: The Dark Side of the Mind, by Travis Langley and with a forward by Carrie Goldman, was also helpful in creating these portraits. This excellent book is a collection of immensely entertaining and enlightening essays and if you are a fan of Star Wars, I recommend it highly!

image_list.subtitle_html: Small Astromech Droid
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: R2-D2's spiritual portrait shows he is pragmatic and logical.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents R2-D2's dominant personality trait, his very strong preference for the logical over the emotional.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  R2-D2 demonstrates this trait in his ability to keep cool and solve problems even when under severe pressure, such as when he stops the trash compactor in Star Wars, A New Hope, saving Luke, Leia, Han, and Chewbacca from being crushed.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents R2-D2's auxiliary personality trait, his very strong preference for facts over ideas.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  R2-D2 demonstrates this trait in his total lack of concern for principles, theories and the big picture, and his complete focus on details, day-to-day events and the concerns of the current moment.

R2-D2 shows his mettle in a race-against-the-clock scene in Episode IV: A New Hope. When Luke Skywalker, Han Solo, and Chewbacca go to rescue Princess Leia aboard an Imperial Cruiser, they end up being slowly crushed in garbage compactor 3263287.

Everyone else — even his fellow droid C-3PO — panics, but R2-D2 calmly saves the day by disabling all of the compactors on that level. While R2-D2 occassionally expresses beeps and whistles that may betray emotion, he proves in this scene he can keep cool and solve problems under pressure.

The Green in R2-D2's spiritual portrait represents his proclivity to use logic and his specialized abilities to solve problems, while ignoring any emotions he might feel.

R2-D2's personality — and his spiritual portrait — stand in stark contrast to the portrait of his constantly-fretting comrade C-3PO. It's Our Lot

Will there come a day when droids need an Emancipation Proclimation or a group like PETA to stand up for them?
